member.name: M:Galaxon.Core.Collections.XEnumerable.Diff``1(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{``0},System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{``0})
member.summary: Return list1 with values from list2 removed. Supports duplicates, so this is not the same as set difference. For example, if list1 has two instances of "cat" and list2 has one instance of "cat", the result will have one instance of "cat".

member.name: M:Galaxon.Core.Collections.XEnumerable.ToDictionary``1(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{``0})
member.summary: Convert an IEnumerable{T} into a dictionary with the dictionary's keys set to the index. This can be useful when the index is meaningful and you want to filter on it.

member.name: M:Galaxon.Core.Enums.XEnum.GetDescription(System.Enum)
member.summary: Get the value of the Description attribute for the enum value, or, if not provided, the name of the value (same as ToString()).

member.name: T:Galaxon.Core.Exceptions.ArgumentFormatException
member.summary: This exception type is useful for an ArgumentException that is also a FormatException. The usual FormatException is probably best reserved for situations not involving method parameters, e.g. parsing a file. I'm using the same parameter order here as used by ArgumentNullException and ArgumentOutOfRangeException. i.e. (paramName, message), for consistency. The base class, ArgumentException, has the parameters in a different order, i.e. (message, paramName), which can be confusing. For this reason, I've resolved not to use ArgumentException anymore but to treat it as an abstract base class. This will avoid the issue with the arguments being out of order, and the lack of specificity. Normally for any ArgumentException we want to identify the argument causing the exception (which should be done using nameof()), unless there are several, in which case the offending arguments can be identified in the message.

member.name: M:Galaxon.Core.Exceptions.ArgumentFormatException.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the ArgumentFormatException class.

member.name: M:Galaxon.Core.Exceptions.ArgumentFormatException.#ctor(System.String,System.Exception)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the ArgumentFormatException class with an error message, and (optionally) a reference to the inner exception that is the cause of this exception.

member.name: M:Galaxon.Core.Exceptions.ArgumentFormatException.#ctor(System.String,System.String,System.Exception)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the ArgumentFormatException class with the parameter name, an error message, and (optionally) a reference to the inner exception that is the cause of this exception.

member.name: T:Galaxon.Core.Exceptions.ArgumentInvalidException
member.summary: TODO Rethink the need for this. It essentially replicates the purpose of ArgumentOutOfRangeException. This exception type is useful for an ArgumentException when the argument is invalid for a reason other than being null, out of range, or having an invalid format. I'm using the same parameter order here as used by ArgumentNullException and ArgumentOutOfRangeException, i.e. (paramName, message), for consistency. The base class, ArgumentException, has the parameters in a different order, i.e. (message, paramName), which can be confusing. I've resolved not to use ArgumentException anymore but to treat it as an abstract base class. This will avoid the issue with the arguments being out of order, and the lack of specificity. Normally for any ArgumentException we want to identify the argument causing the exception (which should be done using nameof()), unless there are several, in which case the offending arguments can be identified in the message.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the ArgumentInvalidException class.

member.name: M:Galaxon.Core.Exceptions.ArgumentInvalidException.#ctor(System.String,System.Exception)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the ArgumentInvalidException class with an error message, and (optionally) a reference to the inner exception that is the cause of this exception.

member.name: M:Galaxon.Core.Exceptions.ArgumentInvalidException.#ctor(System.String,System.String,System.Exception)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the ArgumentInvalidException class with the parameter name, an error message, and (optionally) a reference to the inner exception that is the cause of this exception.

member.name: T:Galaxon.Core.Exceptions.DataNotFoundException
member.summary: Exception for when an attempt is made to obtain data from a database, but it isn't found. It's a bit more specific than DataException, and sometimes ObjectNotFoundException is not exactly what is meant.

member.name: T:Galaxon.Core.Exceptions.NoMatchingCaseException
member.summary: This exception type is similar to ArgumentOutOfRangeException, except intended for use in switch statements and expressions, when the value being tested matches none of the case patterns.

member.name: T:Galaxon.Core.Numbers.ConvertBase
member.summary:
This class supports conversion between integers and strings of digits in a specified base, which can be in the range 2..64.
All built-in integer types are supported, including Int128, UInt128, and BigInteger.
Most languages support conversion to and from base 2 to 36, formed from the 10 digits plus the 26 letters in the English alphabet. To this sequence I've appended 28 non-alphanumeric (symbol) ASCII characters in order to extend the range of supported bases to 64. The symbols are appended to the standard 36 digits in ASCII value order. These characters only require 1 byte in UTF-8 and I assume all, or almost all, computer keyboards will support all of them. This has been done to add support for base 64, mainly for my own amusement, and to provide an alternative to bog-standard Base64 encoding (see link).
The most important difference is that this encoding uses 8 bits per base-64 digit, whereas standard base64 encoding uses 5 bits per digit, which is more compressed. Another difference is that the base 64 digits used here are compatible with the digits used by hexadecimal and all other bases.
ASCII provides 32 symbol (or punctuation) characters. The 4 unused characters are '.' (period), ',' (comma), and '_' (underscore), which can be used as group separators (in different contexts), and '"' (double quote) which is the string delimiter in C#.
As in hexadecimal literals, upper-case letters have the same value as lower-case letters. Use the parameter "letterCase" to specify for the result to use all lower- or all upper-case letters. See the method documentation for ToBase() for how to use this parameter. The default is to use lower-case for all letters except for L (see the Digits constant). Upper-case letters are more easily confused with numerals than lower-case. For example: - 'O' can look like '0' - 'I' can look like '1' - 'Z' can look like '2' - 'S' can look like '5' - 'G' can look like '6' - 'B' can look like '8' The only similar problem with lower-case letters is that 'l' can look like '1'. To solve this, upper-case is used for this letter only. (This is the same reason why we use "L" as a suffix for long literals in C#, as a rule.) These days, most fonts, especially those used by IDEs, make it easy enough to distinguish between letters and numbers, so it's not the issue it once was. Multiple coding standards for CSS require lower-case hex digits in color literals. "L" is not a hexadecimal digit, so this behaviour doesn't violate that standard. Other than that, I can't find any standards that mandate one over the other. It seems upper-case is favoured in older languages, lower-case in newer.
The core methods are ToBase() and FromBase(). In addition, convenience methods are provided in the form of "To" and "From" methods for all bases that are a power of 2, and base 10 (decimal), which are the most commonly used: |------------------|------------------------|--------|--------------------------| | Bits per digit | Numeral system | Base | Methods | |------------------|------------------------|--------|--------------------------| | 1 | binary | 2 | ToBin() FromBin() | | 2 | quaternary | 4 | ToQuat() FromQuat() | | 3 | octal | 8 | ToOct() FromOct() | | | decimal | 10 | ToDec() FromDec() | | 4 | hexadecimal | 16 | ToHex() FromHex() | | 5 | triacontakaidecimal * | 32 | ToTria() FromTria() | | 6 | tetrasexagesimal ** | 64 | ToTetra() FromTetra() | |------------------|------------------------|--------|--------------------------|
* The term for base 32 is "duotrigesimal". However, there are multiple methods in use for encoding base 32 digits; the one used here is called "triacontakaidecimal" (see link below), also known as "base32hex". It's the same encoding used in Java in JavaScript. The term is abbreviated here as "Tria" in the names of the conversion methods.
** The term for Base 64 is "tetrasexagesimal". The term is abbreviated here as "Tetra" in the names of the conversion methods.

member.name: M:Galaxon.Core.Numbers.ConvertBase.ToBase``1(``0,System.Byte,System.Nullable{System.Boolean})
member.summary: Convert an integer to a string of digits in a given base. Note, a negative value will be converted to a non-negative value with the same underlying bits. This reflects the behaviour of other base-conversion methods in .NET.
member.param: If letters should be lower-case, upper-case, or default. null = default (all lower-case except for L; see Digits) true = upper-case false = lower-case
member.returns: The string of digits.
member.exception: If the base is out of range.
If T is an unsupported type.

member.name: M:Galaxon.Core.Numbers.ConvertBase.FromBase``1(System.String,System.Byte)
member.summary: Convert a string of digits in a given base into a int. Group separator characters, including spaces, newlines, thin spaces, periods, commas, and underscores, will be ignored.
member.param: A string of digits in the specified base.
The base that the digits in the string are in.
member.returns: The integer equivalent of the digits.
member.exception: If string is null, empty, or whitespace.
If string contains invalid characters for the specified base.
If a cast to the target type failed.
If the resulting value is out of range for the target type.

member.name: M:Galaxon.Core.Numbers.XBigInteger.LeastCommonMultiple(System.Numerics.BigInteger,System.Numerics.BigInteger)
member.summary: Find the smallest integer which is a multiple of both arguments. Synonyms: lowest common multiple, smallest common multiple. For example, the LCM of 4 and 6 is 12. When adding fractions, the lowest common denominator is equal to the LCM of the denominators.
member.returns: The least common multiple.

member.name: M:Galaxon.Core.Numbers.XBigInteger.GreatestCommonDivisor(System.Numerics.BigInteger,System.Numerics.BigInteger)
member.summary: Determine the greatest common divisor of two integers. Synonyms: greatest common factor, highest common factor.

member.name: M:Galaxon.Core.Numbers.XDecimal.Log(System.Decimal)
member.summary:
Calculate the natural logarithm of a decimal. The algorithm is from:
DecimalEx.Log() hangs for very small values, so I made this version, which doesn't. It's tested, fast, and doesn't break with the largest or smallest decimal values.
member.returns: The natural logarithm of the given value.
member.exception: If the argument is less than or equal to 0.

member.name: M:Galaxon.Core.Numbers.XDecimal.Log(System.Decimal,System.Decimal)
member.summary: Logarithm of a decimal in a specified base.
member.returns: The logarithm of z in base b.
member.exception: If the number is less than or equal to 0.
If the base is less than or equal to 0, or equal to 1.

member.name: M:Galaxon.Core.Numbers.XDouble.FuzzyEquals(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary:
Check if 2 double values are equal for practical purposes. If two double values differ only by the least significant bit, this is more likely due to inaccuracies in floating point representations than actual inequality. This code is copied/adapted from Google Guava DoubleMath.fuzzyEquals().
I initially tried the algorithm from the Microsoft documentation, it didn't work in all cases.
member.param: The maximum allowable difference between them.
member.returns: If close enough to equal.

member.name: M:Galaxon.Core.Numbers.XDouble.FuzzyEquals(System.Nullable{System.Double},System.Nullable{System.Double},System.Double)
member.summary: Compare two nullable doubles for fuzzy equality.

member.name: M:Galaxon.Core.Numbers.XDouble.FuzzyIsInteger(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: IsInteger() can be a bit strict. This method allows for some fuzziness.

member.summary: Check if a double is a positive integer, with some fuzziness.

member.name: M:Galaxon.Core.Numbers.XDouble.FuzzyIsNegativeInteger(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Check if a double is a negative integer, with some fuzziness.

member.name: T:Galaxon.Core.Numbers.XInt
member.summary: Extension methods for int.

member.name: M:Galaxon.Core.Numbers.XInt.Sqrt(System.Int32)
member.summary: Get the int closest to the square root of the given int.

member.name: M:Galaxon.Core.Numbers.XInt.Abs(System.Int32)
member.summary: Return the absolute value of an int as a uint. This addresses an issue with int.Abs(), which is that Abs(int.MinValue) can't be expressed as a int, and so wrap-around occurs. Unsigned integer types don't have an Abs() method, so there's no collision.
member.returns: The absolute value as a uint.

member.name: M:Galaxon.Core.Numbers.XInt.GetRandom
member.summary: Get a random int.

member.name: T:Galaxon.Core.Numbers.XLong
member.summary: Extension methods for long.

member.name: M:Galaxon.Core.Numbers.XLong.Pow(System.Int64,System.Int64)
member.summary: Get the long value closest to x^y.

member.name: M:Galaxon.Core.Numbers.XLong.Sqrt(System.Int64)
member.summary: Get the long value closest to x.

member.name: M:Galaxon.Core.Numbers.XLong.Abs(System.Int64)
member.summary: Return the absolute value of a long as a ulong. This addresses an issue with long.Abs(), which is that Abs(long.MinValue) can't be expressed as a long, and so wrap-around occurs. Unsigned integer types don't have an Abs() method, so there's no collision.
member.returns: The absolute value as a ulong.

member.name: M:Galaxon.Core.Numbers.XLong.GetRandom
member.summary: Get a random long.

member.name: M:Galaxon.Core.Numbers.XNumber.DivMod``1(``0,``0)
member.summary: Integer division and modulo operation using floored division. The modulus will always have the same sign as the divisor. Unlike the truncated division and modulo provided by C#'s operators, floored division produces a regular cycling pattern through both negative and positive values of the divisor. It permits things like: bool isOdd = Mod(num, 2) == 1; Trying to do this using the % operator will fail for negative divisors, however. e.g. bool isOdd = num % 2 == 1; In this case, if num is negative 0, num % 2 == -1

member.name: M:Galaxon.Core.Numbers.XNumber.Div``1(``0,``0)
member.summary: Corrected integer division operation.

member.name: M:Galaxon.Core.Numbers.XNumber.Mod``1(``0,``0)
member.summary: Corrected modulo operation.

member.name: M:Galaxon.Core.Numbers.XNumber.Product``1(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{``0})
member.summary: Similar to Sum(), this extension method generates the product of all values in a collection of numbers.

member.name: M:Galaxon.Core.Numbers.XNumber.Product``1(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{``0},System.Func{``0,``0})
member.summary: Similar to Sum(), get a product of all values in the collection, transformed by the supplied function.

member.name: T:Galaxon.Core.Numbers.XSbyte
member.summary: Extension methods for sbyte.

member.name: M:Galaxon.Core.Numbers.XSbyte.Abs(System.SByte)
member.summary: Return the absolute value of an sbyte as a byte. This addresses an issue with sbyte.Abs(), which is that Abs(sbyte.MinValue) can't be expressed as a sbyte, and so wrap-around occurs. Unsigned integer types don't have an Abs() method, so there's no collision.
member.returns: The absolute value as a byte.

member.name: T:Galaxon.Core.Numbers.XShort
member.summary: Extension methods for short.

member.name: M:Galaxon.Core.Numbers.XShort.Abs(System.Int16)
member.summary: Return the absolute value of a short as a ushort. This addresses an issue with short.Abs(), which is that Abs(short.MinValue) can't be expressed as a short, and so wrap-around occurs. Unsigned integer types don't have an Abs() method, so there's no collision.
member.returns: The absolute value as a ushort.

member.summary: Get a random short.

member.name: F:Galaxon.Core.Strings.XString.SmallCapsChars
member.summary: Map from lower-case letters to their Unicode small caps equivalents.

member.name: M:Galaxon.Core.Strings.XString.EqualsIgnoreCase(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: See if 2 strings are equal, ignoring case.

member.name: M:Galaxon.Core.Strings.XString.ReplaceChars(System.String,System.Collections.Generic.Dictionary{System.Char,System.String},System.Boolean)
member.summary: Replace characters in a string with other characters by using a character map. Example use cases: * making a string upper- or lower-case * converting lowercase characters to small caps * making a string superscript or subscript * transliteration/removal of diacritics
member.param: If a character is encountered that is not in the character map, either keep it (true) or skip it (false).
member.returns: The transformed string.

member.name: M:Galaxon.Core.Strings.XString.Repeat(System.String,System.Int32)
member.summary: Construct a new string by repeating a string multiple times.

member.name: M:Galaxon.Core.Strings.XString.Reverse(System.String)
member.summary: Reverse a string. e.g. "You are awesome." becomes ".emosewa era uoY".

member.name: M:Galaxon.Core.Strings.XString.IsPalindrome(System.String)
member.summary: Check if a string is a palindrome.

member.name: M:Galaxon.Core.Strings.XString.StripWhitespace(System.String)
member.summary: Remove whitespace from a string.
member.returns: The string with whitespace characters removed.

member.name: M:Galaxon.Core.Strings.XString.StripBrackets(System.String,System.Boolean,System.Boolean,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Remove brackets (and whatever's between them) from a string.
member.param: If round brackets should be removed.
If square brackets should be removed
If curly brackets should be removed
If angle brackets should be removed
member.returns: The string with brackets removed.

member.name: M:Galaxon.Core.Strings.XString.StripTags(System.String)
member.summary: Strip HTML tags from a string.
member.returns: The string with HTML tags removed.

member.name: M:Galaxon.Core.Strings.XString.IsAscii(System.String)
member.summary: Check if a string contains only ASCII characters.

member.name: M:Galaxon.Core.Strings.XString.ToSmallCaps(System.String)
member.summary: Convert all lower-case letters in a string to their Unicode small caps variant. Only works for English letters, so, if necessary (e.g. if the string is in a different language), you may wish to call AnyAscii.Transliterate() on the string first.

member.name: M:Galaxon.Core.Strings.XString.ToSuperscript(System.String)
member.summary: Render a string with valid integer characters (i.e. minus sign or digits) converted to their Unicode superscript versions.
member.returns: The string of superscript characters.

member.name: M:Galaxon.Core.Strings.XString.ToSubscript(System.String)
member.summary: Render a string with valid integer characters (i.e. minus sign or digits) converted to their Unicode subscript versions.
member.returns: The string of subscript characters.

member.name: M:Galaxon.Core.Strings.XString.ZeroPad(System.String,System.Int32)
member.summary: Pad a string on the left with 0s to make it up to a certain width.
member.param: The minimum number of characters in the the result.
member.returns: The zero-padded string.

member.name: M:Galaxon.Core.Strings.XString.GroupDigits(System.String,System.Char,System.Byte)
member.summary: Given a string of digits, format in groups using the specified group separator and group size. This method is designed for formatting numbers but it could be used for other purposes, since the method doesn't check if the characters are actually digits. It just assumes they are. Apart from saving time, it allows the method to be used for hexadecimal or other bases. Grouping starts from the right. Here's how you would format an integer: "12345678".GroupDigits(',', 3) => "12,345,678" You can chain methods if you need to, e.g. "11111000000001010101".GroupDigits('_', 8) => "1111_10000000_01010101" "11111000000001010101".ZeroPad(24).GroupDigits('_', 8) => "00001111_10000000_01010101" 123456789.ToHex().ZeroPad(8).GroupDigits(' ') => "075b cd15"
member.param: The string, nominally of digits, but can be whatever.
member.returns: The formatted string.

member.name: M:Galaxon.Core.Strings.XString.ToInt(System.String)
member.summary: Convert nullable string to nullable int without throwing. If the string cannot be parsed into an int, return null. Of course, TryParse() can be used, but this method is a bit more concise, and saves time thinking about nulls.

member.name: M:Galaxon.Core.Strings.XString.ToDouble(System.String)
member.summary: Convert nullable string to nullable double without throwing. If the string cannot be parsed into a double, return null.

member.name: M:Galaxon.Core.Strings.XString.ToDecimal(System.String)
member.summary: Convert nullable string to nullable decimal without throwing. If the string cannot be parsed into a decimal, return null.

member.summary: Extension methods for StringBuilder.

member.name: M:Galaxon.Core.Strings.XStringBuilder.Prepend(System.Text.StringBuilder,System.Object)
member.summary: Prepends a StringBuilder with a string. Reflects Append().

member.name: T:Galaxon.Core.Time.ETimeUnit
member.summary: The time units supported by the conversion functions. **Note: This will be deprecated once Galaxon.Quantities is complete.**

member.name: F:Galaxon.Core.Time.ETimeUnit.Nanosecond
member.summary: Nanosecond (ns). 1 ns = 10-9 s = 0.01 ticks

member.name: F:Galaxon.Core.Time.ETimeUnit.Shake
member.summary: Shake. 1 shake = 10-8 s = 10 ns = 0.1 ticks

member.name: F:Galaxon.Core.Time.ETimeUnit.Tick
member.summary: The core time unit used by .NET. 1 tick = 100 ns = 0.1 s = 10-7 s

member.name: F:Galaxon.Core.Time.ETimeUnit.Microsecond
member.summary: Microsecond (s). 1 s = 10-6 s = 1000 ns = 10 ticks

member.name: F:Galaxon.Core.Time.ETimeUnit.Millisecond
member.summary: Millisecond (ms). 1 ms = 10-3 s = 1000 s

member.name: F:Galaxon.Core.Time.ETimeUnit.Second
member.summary: Second (s). 1 second = 10,000,000 ticks

member.name: F:Galaxon.Core.Time.ETimeUnit.Minute
member.summary: Minute (min). 1 min = 60 s

member.name: F:Galaxon.Core.Time.ETimeUnit.Hour
member.summary: Hour (h). 1 h = 60 min = 3600 sec

member.name: F:Galaxon.Core.Time.ETimeUnit.Day
member.summary: Day (d). 1 d = 24 h = 86,400 min. Depending on context, this may refers to an ephemeris day (exactly 86,400 SI seconds), or a solar day, which is slightly longer.

member.name: F:Galaxon.Core.Time.ETimeUnit.Week
member.summary: Week (w). 1 w = 7 d = 168 h

member.name: F:Galaxon.Core.Time.ETimeUnit.Month
member.summary: Month (mon). Ranges in length from 28-31 days. The average Gregorian calendar month length is 30.436875 d = 4.348125 w = 31,556,952 s

member.name: F:Galaxon.Core.Time.ETimeUnit.Year
member.summary: Year (y). This refers to a Gregorian calendar year, which is 365 or 366 days. The average is 365.2425 days. 1 y = 12 mon

member.name: F:Galaxon.Core.Time.ETimeUnit.Decade
member.summary: Decade (dec). 1 dec = 10 y

member.name: F:Galaxon.Core.Time.ETimeUnit.Century
member.summary: Century (c). 1 c = 10 dec = 100 y

member.name: F:Galaxon.Core.Time.ETimeUnit.Millennium
member.summary: Millennium (ky). 1 ky = 10 c = 100 dec = 1000 y

member.name: T:Galaxon.Core.Time.XDateOnly
member.summary: Extension methods for the DateOnly class.

member.name: F:Galaxon.Core.Time.XDateOnly.SortableDatePattern
member.summary: Same as DateTimeFormatInfo.SortableDateTimePattern, but without the time.

member.name: M:Galaxon.Core.Time.XDateOnly.ToIsoString(System.DateOnly)
member.summary: Format the date using ISO 8601 format YYYY-MM-DD.
member.returns: A string representing the date in ISO format.

member.name: M:Galaxon.Core.Time.XDateOnly.ToDateTime(System.DateOnly)
member.summary: Convert a DateOnly to a DateTime, with default time 00:00:00.
member.returns: The new DateTime object

member.name: M:Galaxon.Core.Time.XDateOnly.ToDateTime(System.DateOnly,System.DateTimeKind)
member.summary: Convert a DateOnly to a DateTime, with default time 00:00:00 and specified DateTimeKind.
member.returns: The new DateTime object

member.name: M:Galaxon.Core.Time.XDateOnly.GetTicks(System.DateOnly)
member.summary: Get the number of ticks between the start of the epoch (0001-01-01 00:00:00) and the start of the date. If extension properties are added to the language I may change this to a property "Ticks" later, for consistency with DateTime.
member.returns: The number of ticks.

member.name: M:Galaxon.Core.Time.XDateOnly.GetTotalSeconds(System.DateOnly)
member.summary: Get the number of seconds between the start of the epoch and the start of the date.
member.returns: The number of seconds since the epoch start.

member.name: M:Galaxon.Core.Time.XDateOnly.GetTotalDays(System.DateOnly)
member.summary: Get the number of days between the start of the epoch and the given date.
member.returns: The number of days since the epoch start.

member.name: M:Galaxon.Core.Time.XDateOnly.GetTotalYears(System.DateOnly)
member.summary: Get the number of years between the start of the epoch and the start of the date. The result will be greater than or equal to `date.Year - 1` and less than `date.Year`.
member.returns: The number of years since the epoch start.

member.name: M:Galaxon.Core.Time.XDateOnly.Add(System.DateOnly,System.TimeSpan)
member.summary: Add a period of time to a date to find a new DateTime.
member.returns: The resulting DateTime.

member.name: M:Galaxon.Core.Time.XDateOnly.Add(System.DateOnly,System.TimeOnly)
member.summary: Add a time of day to a date to find a new DateTime.
member.param: The time of day to add.
member.returns: The resulting DateTime.

member.name: M:Galaxon.Core.Time.XDateOnly.AddWeeks(System.DateOnly,System.Int32)
member.summary: Add a number of weeks to a date.
member.param: The number of weeks to add.
member.returns: The resulting date.

member.name: M:Galaxon.Core.Time.XDateOnly.Subtract(System.DateOnly,System.DateOnly)
member.summary:
Returns the difference between two dates as a number of days. Emulates the
method. If the end date is later than the start date, the result will be positive. If they are equal, the result will be zero. Otherwise, the result will be negative.
member.returns: The number of days difference between the two dates.

member.name: M:Galaxon.Core.Time.XDateOnly.FromTotalDays(System.Int64)
member.summary: Find a date given the number of days from the start of the epoch.
member.returns: The resulting date.

member.name: M:Galaxon.Core.Time.XDateOnly.FromTotalYears(System.Double)
member.summary: Find the date given the number of years since the start of the epoch.
member.param: The number of years. May include a fractional part.
member.returns: The resulting date.

member.name: M:Galaxon.Core.Time.XDateOnly.FromDayOfYear(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Find a date given a year and the day of the year. Formula from Meeus (Astronomical Algorithms 2 ed. p66).
member.returns: The resulting date.

member.name: M:Galaxon.Core.Time.XDateOnly.ToJulianDay(System.DateOnly)
member.summary: Convert a DateOnly object to a Julian Day value. The result gives the Julian Day at the start of the given date (00:00:00, i.e. midnight), which will always have a fraction of 0.5, since a Julian Day starts at 12:00:00 (noon).
member.returns: The Julian Day value.

member.name: M:Galaxon.Core.Time.XDateOnly.FromJulianDay(System.Double)
member.summary: Convert a Julian Day value to a date.
member.param: The Julian Day value. If a fractional part indicating the time of day is included, this information will be discarded.
member.returns: A new DateOnly object.

member.name: M:Galaxon.Core.Time.XDateOnly.GetEaster(System.Int32)
member.summary: Get the date of Easter Sunday in the given year. Formula is from Wikipedia. This method uses the "Meeus/Jones/Butcher" algorithm from 1876, with the New Scientist modifications from 1961. Tested for years 1600..2299.
member.returns: The date of Easter Sunday for the given year.

member.name: M:Galaxon.Core.Time.XDateOnly.GetChristmas(System.Int32)
member.summary: Get the date of Christmas Day in the given year.
member.returns: The date of Christmas in the given year.

member.name: M:Galaxon.Core.Time.XDateOnly.GetNthWeekdayInMonth(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.DayOfWeek)
member.param: Which occurence of the day of the week within the month.
member.returns: The requested date.
member.exception: If Abs(n) not in the range 1..5
If a valid date could not be found.

member.name: M:Galaxon.Core.Time.XDateOnly.GetThanksgiving(System.Int32,System.String)
member.summary: Find the date of Thanksgiving for a specified country in a given year. Only years with a holiday called "Thanksgiving" are supported. The default is "US".
member.returns: The date of Thanksgiving.
member.exception: Either this country doesn't celebrate Thanksgiving, or the method doesn't support it.

member.name: T:Galaxon.Core.Time.XDateTime

member.name: F:Galaxon.Core.Time.XDateTime.JulianPeriodOffset
member.summary: The number of days from the start of the Julian period to the start of the epoch used by .NET (0001-01-01 00:00:00 UTC).

member.name: M:Galaxon.Core.Time.XDateTime.ToIsoString(System.DateTime)
member.summary: Format the date using ISO format YYYY-MM-DDThh:mm:ss. This format is useful for databases. The time zone is not shown. For that, call ToString() with the format specifier "U" or UniversalSortableDateTimePattern. See
member.returns: A string representing the datetime in ISO format.

member.name: M:Galaxon.Core.Time.XDateTime.AddWeeks(System.DateTime,System.Double)
member.summary: Add a number of weeks to a DateTime to get a new DateTime.
member.param: The number of weeks to add.

member.summary: Get the date part of a DateTime as a DateOnly object. An alternative to the Date property, which returns a DateTime.
member.returns: The date part of the DateTime.

member.name: M:Galaxon.Core.Time.XDateTime.GetTimeOnly(System.DateTime)
member.summary: Get the time part of a DateTime as a TimeOnly object. An alternative to the TimeOfDay property, which returns a TimeSpan.
member.returns: The time part of the DateTime.

member.name: M:Galaxon.Core.Time.XDateTime.GetTotalSeconds(System.DateTime)
member.summary: Get the total number of seconds from the start of the epoch to the datetime.
member.returns: The number of seconds since the epoch start.

member.name: M:Galaxon.Core.Time.XDateTime.GetTotalDays(System.DateTime)
member.summary: Get the total number of days from the start of the epoch to the datetime.
member.returns: The number of days since the epoch start.

member.name: M:Galaxon.Core.Time.XDateTime.GetTotalYears(System.DateTime)
member.summary: Get the number of years between the start of the epoch and the start of the date.
member.returns: The number of years since the epoch start.

member.name: M:Galaxon.Core.Time.XDateTime.FromTotalSeconds(System.Double)
member.summary: Create a new DateTime given the number of seconds since the start of the epoch.
member.returns: A new DateTime object.

member.name: M:Galaxon.Core.Time.XDateTime.FromTotalDays(System.Double)
member.summary: Create a new DateTime given the number of days since the start of the epoch.
member.param: The number of days. May include a fractional part indicating the time of day.
member.returns: A new DateTime object.

member.name: M:Galaxon.Core.Time.XDateTime.FromTotalYears(System.Double)
member.summary: Create a new DateTime given the number of years since the start of the epoch.
member.param: The number of years. May include a fractional part.
member.returns: A new DateTime object.

member.name: M:Galaxon.Core.Time.XDateTime.ToJulianDay(System.DateTime)
member.summary: Express the DateTime as a Julian Day. The time of day information in the DateTime will be expressed as the fractional part of the return value. Note, however, a Julian Day begins at 12:00 noon.
member.returns: The Julian Day value

member.name: M:Galaxon.Core.Time.XDateTime.FromJulianDay(System.Double)
member.summary: Convert a Julian Day value to a DateTime object.
member.param: The Julian Day value. May include a fractional part indicating the time of day.
member.returns: A new DateTime object.

member.name: T:Galaxon.Core.Time.XTimeOnly
member.summary: Extension methods for TimeOnly.

member.name: M:Galaxon.Core.Time.XTimeOnly.ToTimeSpan(System.TimeOnly)
member.summary: Convert a TimeOnly to a TimeSpan.
member.returns: The new TimeSpan object

member.name: M:Galaxon.Core.Time.XTimeOnly.Subtract(System.TimeOnly,System.TimeOnly)
member.summary: Subtract a start time from an end time to find the difference.
member.returns: The time elapsed.

member.name: T:Galaxon.Core.Time.XTimeSpan
member.summary: Additional members to supplement the TimeSpan class. Mostly constants. For consistency with TimeSpan, I've used `long` as the type for any integer constants. For non-integer constants I've used `double`. The following constants are already provided by the TimeSpan class and not reproduced here: - TicksPerMicrosecond - TicksPerMillisecond - TicksPerSecond - TicksPerMinute - TicksPerHour - TicksPerDay **NOTE: Any constants or methods for converting between time units will become obsolete with the completion of Galaxon.Quantities.** The word Month, Year, Decade, Century, or Millennium in a constant name usually refers to the average length of that time unit in the Gregorian Calendar.

member.name: M:Galaxon.Core.Time.XTimeSpan.Convert(System.Double,Galaxon.Core.Time.ETimeUnit,Galaxon.Core.Time.ETimeUnit)
member.summary: Convert a time value from one unit to another. TODO Replace with Quantity methods.
member.returns: The amount of the new unit.

member.name: F:Galaxon.Core.Time.XTimeSpan.MinutesPerHour
member.summary: The number of minutes in an hour.

member.name: F:Galaxon.Core.Time.XTimeSpan.MinutesPerDay
member.summary: The number of minutes in a day.

member.name: F:Galaxon.Core.Time.XTimeSpan.HoursPerDay
member.summary: The number of hours in an ephemeris day.

member.name: F:Galaxon.Core.Time.XTimeSpan.HoursPerWeek
member.summary: The number of hours in a week.

member.name: F:Galaxon.Core.Time.XTimeSpan.WeeksPerMonth
member.summary: The number of weeks in an average Gregorian month.

member.name: F:Galaxon.Core.Time.XTimeSpan.YearsPerDecade
member.summary: The number of years in a decade. The precise length of a decade depends on what year is being used. For a example, a Gregorian decade (3652.425 d on average) will have a different length to an Islamic Calendar decade (about 3543.67 d on average) or a tropical decade (3652.42198781 d on average).

member.name: F:Galaxon.Core.Time.XTimeSpan.YearsPerCentury
member.summary: The number of years in a century.

member.summary: The number of years in a millennium.

member.name: F:Galaxon.Core.Time.XTimeSpan.YearsPerSolarCycle
member.summary:
The Gregorian Calendars repeats on a 400-year cycle called the *solar cycle*. There are 97 leap years in that period, giving an average calendar year length of 365 + (97/400) = 365.2425 days/year. 1 Gregorian solar cycle = 400 y = 4800 mon = 20,871 w = 146,097 d 5 Gregorian solar cycles = 2000 y = 2 ky Solar cycles are not ordinarily numbered, nor given a specific start date. However, within the proleptic Gregorian epoch (the one used by .NET), which began on Monday, 1 Jan, 1 AD, we are currently in the 6th solar cycle. It began on Monday, 1 Jan, 2001, which was also the first day of the 3rd millennium AD. It will end on Sunday, 31 Dec, 2400. See: -
-

member.summary: The number of seconds in a solar day (as at 2023). It is increasing by about 2 milliseconds per century.

member.name: F:Galaxon.Core.Time.XTimeSpan.DaysPerTropicalYear
member.summary: The number of days in the mean tropical year B1900 (days). This value is taken from the SOFA (Standards of Fundamental Astronomy) library, which is assumed to be authoritative.
